values:
So, I've not updated here for a while.

I just finished <strike>beating a dead horse</strike> writing my play for Papatango and the deadline is the end of this month. I sent it off and they release the long list in July.

I have a back up theatre to send it to if I don't make it to the long list (I think I've done really well with what I wrote but am also used to not giving people what they want) and it's not too bad to only wait a couple of months before you can submit to others because you've failed. A lot of other writing things will keep you waiting for ages and then you don't get anywhere.

I do like this comp though as the prize is brilliant. Winner gets a 4 week run of their play. It actually gets put on, you have no idea how difficult that is to get done at a real theatre, especially in London, especially for a nobody. Runner up gets a 3 week run.

I would be delighted to be a runner up. Having something actually produced and performed and a proper writing credit is what I really need/want. Money totally isn't a factor. Writing and having a shit job to earn money is how it is and I'm resigned to that.

BBC Writersroom have changed the unsolicited submissions rules to a seasonal opening when you can send stuff in. All well and good there, I'll never make the first deadline but aiming to send a script every open season is doable.

I also got an email from Contrary telling me they are open for submissions for the next issue now.

If I can get play written and out, short story written and out and a script written and out I will feel a lot more productive than I have recently.

I have been doing stuff, and I haven't been writer's blocked, but I've been doing that 'just do that, just do this, have a sit down to write later' thing.

Oh and then I got a numb forearm from the way I sit at the table to type. I think I lift my arms up too high to type. I have Movelat gel but I'm not sure it's really done much (apart from cost me money)

I'm a twat now.

Meaning I'm on Twitter. (@sltsm_smith)

Handy for updates on writing things, Papatango are on there and BBC Writersroom. James Henry and Moffat are also being followed by me so it's all motivation-y.

Though the main reason I got it was to <strike>stalk</strike> follow Arthur Darvill.

We are honored that you considered our publication worthy to receive your writing, we thank you for the opportunity to read your work, and we regret that we are unable to publish it at this time. Please consider the numerical reality: that for each issue, we are able to publish much less than one percent of the submissions we receive.
Because we were particularly fond of your submission, very soon you will receive another email inviting you to submit different work for the next issue, so please watch for that. We wish you the very best of luck, we hope you will keep in touch, and we hope that we may continue to read each other.

Ever yours,


The editors of Contrary

Jeff McMahon
Shaindel Beers
Frances Badgett
Cynthia Newberry Martin
http://contrarymagazine.com
 So I don't know if this is the standard wording for their 'not this time' emails but it's a very flattering and openly encouraging let down. On submission I noticed that what I sent was way too long so I was pretty sure the no would be based on that. Seems that despite the length they still sat and read it all. *continues plugging away*

As I'm sure we all suspect, the Internet is the biggest distraction in the modern world.

I, for example, had a book to finish reading and another to start, but I only read at the launderette while waiting for my washing to get done.

From when I got up yesterday morning to when I went to bed my mobile broadband just wasn't working. I tried several times every hour and it wasn't having it. I even stood on the balcony to try and gett a stronger signal and it wouldn't connect.

I'd resigned myself to having to take the netbook to the Orange store today to get them to sort it out. I can't do it over the phone as I'm out of credit and I can't add credit until Monday because I'm out of money and I don't get any money in the bank until Monday.

Phew!

So, while not being on the Internet I finished Be My Enemy (which didn't end with nearly as much slaughter as I'd prepared myself for) and started David Rooney's book on the Belville family. Reading the bood really got my note taking juices flowing and I had to read with a pen and paper next to me. Then I decided I want to go to the museum in Guildhall where the chronometer is so I can see it for real. Then I made two brainstorming charts and got my screenwriting course notebook and forund the Hero's Journey printout and wrote each header and left a few lines and then started to fill in what I had and what I planned and then looked at the gaps in the narative I needed to fill and what I could feasably leave out.

I'm going to work off off my first draft and write it from the beginning from scratch. I NEVER do that!

What I'm thinking is that the thing about the older mentor giving advice, you get that a lot and it's part of the formula and it works so don't ditch it just for the sake of ditching it...but don't crowbar it in just for the sake of having one. It will stand out as a cliche and not work. I keep thinking about the first episode of Misfits as I write this. They don't have an older sage to give them advice. Tony? I don't think so, they run from him and he's not in the mentor role for the rest of the first series. Just the speech in the opening sequence isn't enough for him to be the encouraging wise man.

Misfits ep 1 also didn't end with them returning to the same situation they began in (the return to normality). You could say that it ended with what now has to be their normality but I think it's better to end a pilot ep at point 12, the hero emerges from the adventure, changed.

I'm also comparing it to the first ep because that hooked people in to want to see what happened next but could also be viewed as a stand alone story.

So I need a hook but not an out and out cliffhanger.

*nods with resolve*

It really is amazing how focused you get when you have no Internet connection!

*pulls determined face*

So I have Celtx on both my computers.

I have a doc file of just notes.

I just wrote a dialogue back and forth on a piece of paper, then turned it over and divided it into 15 boxes ready for me to write a plan for my pilot eipsode.

Before I leap into this I'd like a proper opinion.

Here's the thing. I started out sending the BBC comedy scripts.

They reacted by soliciting me for more of the same.

Then they called me in to do a workshop on drama.

So did they know I was sending them comedy? Is my comedy drama to normal people?

Okay, I thought, they want drama from me, so I wrote some drama for them.

Nothing.

Here what I want your truthful opinion on.

Should I write as if I'm writing a comedy but send it in as a drama OR should I try to write a drama because that's what they liked from me and tried to nurture?

I heard from them and they went for a 'new take on the zombie genre'

*tumbleweed blows by*

Did they not see Shaun of the Dead?

If I'd known they just wanted a mindless rip off I'd have pitched an episode of Doctor Who to them!

So I was at the screening of episode 1 of Misfits last night. There was Q&A with Robert Sheehan, Lauren Soca, Howard Overman and Tom Green the director. Wossy was also there in an orange ASBO boiler suit. Afterwards there was a workshop that was originally going to be us coming up with ideas for the show but the producers made them change that at the last minute (for plagiarism reasons IMO. If one of us came up with an idea they had already planned then we could claim they copied us and be wanky about it). The change email stated -
I am writing to inform you that the Misfits workshop will now be different to previously advertised. We have had to change the format of the workshop at the request of Clerkenwell Films.  The workshop will no longer be character based, instead you are invited to join the series' cast and crew in a workshop where you'll find out more about the show and the processes behind creating a TV series. Everyone who attends the workshop will be given the opportunity to write a pitch for their own TV show and one lucky winner will be invited to for a meeting at Clerkenwell Films to discuss their idea further.
 
I apologise for any inconvenience caused by this alteration.
 The bolding is mine, to make a point, as when we sat there they informed us that they were only accepting pitches from under 25's. Shoc pointed out that this wasn't explained at the end of the workshop and they gave her reasons that it was. Thus my bolding because it totally wasn't! I also didn't let this go and brought it up with the producer from Clerkenwell myself. She'd said that it was a massive opportunity writers never get and only 10 of us were getting it and aren't they great. She also said that nobody takes unsolicited material but the BBC Writersroom (yup, already in with them thank you). So they asked for questions and I asked, obviously not sure word for word but basically this, "So you pointed out that the only people listening to unsolicited material is the BBC Writersroom and you, tonight, but I've been deemed too old to take part so does that mean my only avenue left is the Writersroom?" She told me that I should write for theatre first (FYI I starred out with novel length fiction, novel length non fiction, radio plays, stage plays, and then went onto screen writing as all those routes are impossible to break into but screen writing wasn't. Now she says it is and to go back to theatre again.) Then she said I should work with a theatre company (hello? Habbit Shed for about 5 years. Contacts at Chicken Shed too. Gets you anywhere? No.) These are great things to fob off teenagers but I'm 34 and as I said to her myself, "I've paid my dues". I found the advice Chris Fallon gave us in the Screen Writing course more productive. He said that you need an agent and the best way to get one and use one is by writing two outstanding scripts, resigning yourself to the fact nobody will ever make them, and get an agent to show them around as examples of your work and you'll get asked to write other things off the back of them. I said this to her too. The most productive thing she actually said to me was that it was totally true but you don't need two, you can just have one magnificent no holds barred script to get you episodes of other people's shows. She later spoke about how you will get endless rejections and turned and gestured to me. I waved my hands in the air and said 'Woo!' As I said, after the workshop was over Shoc cornered the BFI man and pointed out the age restriction thing wasn't ever made clear and he disagreed and said it was written somewhere and she said that he was happy to take the money of over 25's and that was when I joined then and said 'Yeah, what's with the ageism? I'm not old!' He told me to write in anyway, under a made up name, and if I get to the next stage then tell them I'm actually 34. he said if they really like my pitch they should let that go. So I have his card and will do it on principle.

My screen writing tutor, Chris Fallon, told us something from his life in the last lesson.

He wrote his first script and loads of people loved it and he got an agent from it and other jobs and commissions etc.

Eventually a guy at Channel 4 wanted to make it. He re wrote and re wrote for 6 months until the Channel 4 guy said 'we've killed this haven't we?'. It was abandoned.

Later ITV made an identical drama with Helena Bonham Carter in it. Plots, characters, locations, IDENTICAL. Chris got ripped off. There was nothing he could do.

From the ITV one off special, Mirimax wanted to do a Hollywood version. The man from Channel 4 was now working at Mirimax. The person who was most enthused at Mirimax left them and went to Dreamworks.

They agreed to split projects and do two different versions of the ITV drama.

One of them made Forces of Nature with Sandra Bullock and one made Runaway Bride with Julia Roberts.

At this point of telling us the story Chris facepalms and we all groan.

He said he was so disheartened that he went a whole other way and directed Eastenders for a couple of years.

He came back to writing after that.

I never thought writers got much protection, recognition or respect in the industry so I wasn't surprised.

Two weeks ago Chris had been struggling to explain to the class that nobody's going to bend over backwards to help you for free as a writer. At least 3 of the students were boggling at this.

I've never felt like such a cynical pro in my life!

Chris Fallon read my latest BBC rejection letter tonight and he said the main focus of everything we'll cover is going to be the 'film language' that they Beeb's script reader was asking for. There's also a stand up comedian who's been asked to produce a script for apilot and he hasn't a clue about writing for TV so he's doing the course. I let him read it through so he could see what feedback from the tv producers looks like. I did point out that most will just send you a computer printout with your name and your title pasted in to a template. We wrote some dialogue free opening scenes and then discussed stroy structure and how the opening scenes for films compare to the novels they were based on. I mentioned that a lot of situation comedy want every ep to resolve so it's right back to the status quo and the episodes could be watched in any order as there's no linear story arc to follow. While I was making a curry for my dinner he emailed me. Hi Shari,
I just wanted to get back to you about your thoughts this evening on Story.  I'm glad to hear the Writer's Room talked about the Hero's Journey -- that's a very important perspective, which I hope we'll be able to spend some time on.  I'm really glad too that they related it to "Life On Mars" --
You're right to say that in a lot of sitcoms, for instance, things don't appear to change.  Very often the characters at the end of the episode, despite all the conflicts and upheavals in the episode, are back where they started at the end.  Balance has been restored, the status quo maintained.  We see this in shows like Friends, for instance, where despite the conflicts there's generally a fairly positive resolution that restores harmony.   But over the considerable arc of several series there is change, as characters develop, fall in love, get engaged etc.
In The Office, the unchanging monotonous nature of the environment was one of its key elements, but over the course of the two series, Dawn and Tim finally do get together, and even David Brent finds love.
One of the key elements of British episodic drama, unfortunately (Life On Mars being a great exception), is there isn't much change - in a series like Casualty for instance, the change is effected mainly on the people who come into the hospital - a patient might go from being in denial about their cocaine addiction, for instance, to finally recognising their problem and their need for help.
Anyway,I just wanted to get back to you as there wasn't time at the end of the class. 
Have a good week.
best wishes
Chris

My Five Days in May - Dagenham perspective - is done.

How's that for rapid response BBC?

10 minute original script without notice, done in a day.

I'm good!

<lj-cut text="Writing this month so far"><U>7th Feb</U>
I feel the need for some big unique plot thing to be going on along with the character development and am drawing a blank.

<U>11th Feb</U>
I be writing a script!

And *flails with glee* on the train home I actually jumped up as I thought of my plottal thing to go with my lovely situation and characters.

I jumped up as we pulled into Maryland station (always makes me think of the cookies *lol*) and I had to pretend to look out of the window, realise this wasn;t my stop and I was mistaken, and then sit down until I got to Stratford.

*cheers self*

I have scenes and notes and some dialogue down already. I just have to pull it all together properly and then weave the plot into it.

My notes and dialogue is 12 pages long. In scripts you count it as a minute a page so throw in the cuts, shots and scene set ups, then all the descriptive stuff (consider I have sign language in the story there's gonna be a LOT of description) I must have at the very least a half hour to forty minutes prepared.

It'll either be a one hour part one or an hour and a half stand alone. I'm thinking of the over an hour all in one being best.

Even if they don't want it it'll put me back on the radar for when I spam them with more during the year.

They already told me a fast turnover of a decent standard could get me an ep of somebody elses' series.

Look at me all driven and focused!

<u>Today</u>
I wanted to write DUSK.

I wrote DUCK.

Now I'm wondering if a massive duck can be incorporated into the scene without it needing to be explained.

I doubt it *lol*</lj-cut>

So I'm now in a 34 page doc file with 26 pages actually written and formatted into scenes and dialogue. I'm on scene 6 now.

I'm setting myself an end of the month deadline and I'm not thinking it's that unrealistic.

Quick question, I have a deaf character with a hearing brother and a hired interpreter as go between for them who has tinnitus.

Now after research I found out that in my location the deaf society does also host tinnitus support groups so that's realistic enough but do you think it's too...metaphorical maybe? Too symbolic or clunky to have a character who can't hear a thing and one who hears too much?

Honest opinions on that please.

Is it that I'm right to worry it's a bit much or am I just thinking it's too obvious because it's my idea?

Title: Adversary

Okay, you've messed with me for the last time.

I'm not having it.

Our nation, our whole society, was built on queuing. I have been in the queue for five minutes and you've been in yours, a separate queue for about the same amount of time.

Ah but I see what you're doing and I won't let you get away with it!

Edging over ever so slightly because mine's moving faster. You're trying to make out that it's one long queue that splits in two at the checkouts. You're trying to slip in front of me and then shrug and say, 'But it's all one big queue'.

NO!

Push behind me, I don't care, but try and crowbar in front of me and I will be the most English person there has ever been in the history of the world.

I'll be more English than King Harold. More English than Boadicea.

Yes, I am so English I pronounce it Bodicea instead of Boudica!

That is how English I will be.

You take that step, that inoffensive step that will form one queue from two and slide you in front of me without looking like blatant pushing in. You move and I speak at the same moment.

"I don't think so."

You look at me and smile, "Oh sorry, I was just moving out of somebody's way."

Smile back and all is well, separate queues and no pushing in.

It was like the Battle of Hastings, only my Harold is wearing goggles.

Take that. Ha!

Title: Clairvoyant 

Two boys in a small tent on a grubby fairground stopped sniggering.

"Which one of you is to know your future?"

"Can't you do us both?"

"You gave me money for one, I tell one future."

The boys looked at each other.

"Well we do all the same things anyway. If my football teams wins then so does yours"

"Yeah, it'll be the same for both of us," the other agreed.

"So you do it."

"No, you do it."

"It's your money."

"And you were the one who wanted to do it."

"But you're paying."

"It's my treat, go for it."

"Don't go spending your money on me, I'm fine."

"Here, tell his future," the boy put the money down on the table."

"No, do his, his money, his future."

"Look I'm telling you-"

"For this once, I will do two for price of one," the fortune teller said as she raised her hand to silence them and slid the money into her lap with the other.

"Okay." Both boys said.

"I see it very clearly. I see both of you, not too far away, not too much older."

They nodded.

"And?"

"You drifting further and further apart, until no longer friends."

"Bollocks!" One of the boys said.

"Is what I see. You argue, you grow apart, and you never the same again."

"That's obviously made up, details please Mystic Meg?" The other huffed.

"You no longer friends because rich one stops paying for poor one. Poor one doesn't want to know rich one without hand outs. Rich one doesn't want friend who only wants money."

"That's rubbish, I never want his money!"

"He never takes it!"

She smiled and shrugged.

"This is bull, come on, we're going."

Both boys got up and left.

A big swarthy man peered through the curtains behind her.

"Easy enough, that one."

"Yeah," the fortune teller said as she lit a cigarette, "if they weren't gonna fall out over money they bloody well are now!"

Title: Elephant Photo It looked like fire and smoke a long way away, but they weren't scared. They walked towards the glow of the fire, like they did every evening. The air cooled and the flies seemed to stop bothering them. It was the perfect time of day. It was safe too. There was no light for the snapping noises that made their fellows fall down in pain. When they saw others who had fallen their tusks had been taken, only stumps left behind. They would mourn for the stranger but the evening fire felt like a passing soul. They could go on because the sky burned. Always walking towards the golden light. Always until the air snapped and they fell on their way.

Title: True Intentions

She'd thought it was easy. They kept on telling her how easy it was. Get a rich man from the west, get him to take you home, get him to marry you, get pregnant, get set up for life!

So she found a white man from England and he took her home for a six month visit and she saw his house and the homes of his family and thought, yes, this is the life I want.

So when she told him she loved him and he said it back she thought cha-ching. Only he sold everything he owned and gave up his job...and moved to the east with her.

He was happy with the good exchange rate and cheap cost of living and heat and food. She was living in her home town and not getting married or the free money for not working or the free money for having a baby or the free house.

She wanted the free house.

All her friends who had married English men had said they got free money, called benefits, and a free house that they didn't have to pay for.

She wanted her free house.

It took two years of being in love and spending his money until he ran out and needed to go back home to real life and get a job again. She played the loving him angle. She loved him so much and wanted to come with him and she'd be willing to live in that cold rainy country to be with him.

Another visa and she was back in the west.

He'd sold his house and she'd spent his money. They had to live with his elderly parents. Not to worry, she told herself, the free house would come soon.

She asked about the free houses at dinner and everybody laughed. They tried to tell her there were no such things as free houses. She understood now, it was supposed to be a secret. She played along for a while.

When they got engaged and her visa was extended they still didn't mention the free houses and free money. When she got pregnant there was still no word. She went to a temple a few miles away and spoke to another from her home town who married a South African man.

She laughed at her too when she asked of the free house and money. 

"They are all poor here, nothing is free for poor people, only people who don't need free things. Family in South Africa feel sorry for us because this country so poor!"

So even the other ladies from the east keep the secret. She would play along for longer.

They were married before the baby came. The visa changed again and now, at last, there must be a free house for the half English baby.

"There aren't free houses, I told you," her husband said.

"But you get place to live without buying it, you said we're waiting for house."

"Yeah, a council house. They don;t give you a house, they let you live in their house and you pay rent. You pay to live in somebody else's house, it's not free."

Right, maybe the information she was given was wrong. But his mother's house was big and nice and she and his father were very old and frail.

"When mum and dad die, we get their house free, yes?"

"No!" He looked at her strangely. "They rent their house too. When they die the house is rented to somebody else. It's still the council's house."

"But when people die, children get their money, yes?"

"If they have money. My mum and dad don;t have anything."

"So where will we get money?"

"We'll work," he laughed.

She was married, she was pregnant, she was committed to life in another country.

When she spoke to friends back home she didn't tell them the stories of the west weren't true, she'd lose face.

And she couldn't complain that her rich English family were poor...there was going to be a child now. The child should think it was born out of love and never know its mother's true intentions.

Title: Slow Dance

During the bouncy dances, the lively numbers, disco and pop and various other tunes that would cause humiliation for the uncoordinated, people endlessly torment those who opt to sit out.

Somebody will gyrate over and grab at the sitter, pulling and tugging and complaining that the sitter is boring, before dancing away without a care for how ridiculous they look.

They are the people who use that phrase 'dance like nobody's watching' as if this is a good concept.

Nobody tries to drag people out of their shells during the slow songs. 

Nobody will force a dance on people in that situation. That would be too intimate, a sign of desperation rather than fun.

That's when those sitting out will stand up. They will dance closely with a partner, either romantic or platonic, family or friend, and display a closeness and a comfort that the bouncy people don't understand and can't replicate.

They are the ones who sit the dance out now.

Watching from the sidelines.

They have to dance like nobody's watching, because they have nobody to watch them in the first place.

We dance the slow dances, and always with the person who watches our back.

Title: Soporific She says she's an insomniac too so she knows what I'm going through. We can sit up in bed together, she says with a smile. Or I toss and turn all night while her nose does this whistle-y thing as she sleeps. She tells people that we're both insomniac and I smile through gritted teeth and nod. Everybody she tells has miracle cures, home remedies, and suggest Kalms from the chemist. Half of them say they have insomnia too. Sometimes it takes them up to three hours to drop off. Poor dears. Oh yes, it's so hard, my girlfriend agrees. I grind my teeth and nod along. Yes, yes, you all have insomnia. Insomnia means you take a little while to fall asleep. You all know exactly what I'm going through but you manage not to complain about it or look a state. THAT'S BECAUSE YOU DON'T FUCKING HAVE IT! Her nose whistles and I poke her in the side. She jumps and sits up in bed. "What's up?" "Nothing." "So why did you wake me up?" "I couldn't have woken you, we're insomniacs." "What?" "You were asleep. It's not even two o'clock and you were asleep. You don't get to say to people you're an insomniac any more. You're not and you never were." "What's wrong with you?" She demands, angrily. "What's wrong with me? What's wrong with me? I'm an Insomniac!

Title: Gossamer

"This is your web.

This is your web on drugs."

The class laughed as the slides changed and the web spun by a spider in a lab test showed a broken and disjointed web, abandoned halfway through.

"That's a fake," a surly kid from the back muttered.

"But so what if it is? This example made a better point than a smashed egg ever did. 

People's heads don't explode if they smoke a joint. But people's minds do wander, jobs aren't done quite the same way, and different drugs do make your brain do different things."

The teacher got through to every one of his class that day, except for the broody know it all at the back.

The spider on drugs lesson always went down well, for ten more years it went down well. Even the broody know it alls appreciated that an effort had been made not to patronise them.

After ten years, the lesson changed.

"This is your web. This is your web on drugs."

The laugh, the lecture, and then an added slide.

"And this is your web if you ignore this speech, go off the rails, overdose, go into rehab, come out of rehab and have an exhibition at an art gallery called Tate Modern called 'Gossamer'."

The last slide was a photograph from brooding know it all's installation piece. A series of disjointed webs spun from silk thread, steel wire, and fine glass.

"It really saves you a lot of time and therapy if you listen to me now," the teacher smiled.

Title: Malign

He strode about the room with a look of utter contempt on his face.

You might not be able to judge a book by its cover but you can definitely judge a person by their bedroom, he thought to himself.

What kind of slob would live like this?

He didn't want to touch anything, even the air seemed to leave dirty marks, and he ran his finger along thin air before examining it for dust particles. There weren't any but that didn't stop him from wanting to wear one of those face masks people in Tokyo wear on the streets.

Maybe Global warming was caused by this room.

Maybe the inconvenient truth was that this person was not a human but a waste industry.

There should be toxic hazard tape around the walls. He felt biochemical warfare taking place at the back of his throat. Even his feet appeared to stick to the carpet.

He looked down to see there wasn't actually any carpet, it was a hardwood floor that was covered in something matted and hairy.

He left the room, in disgust, and waited in the tackily decorated living room for the cause of this devastation to return home.

This was eviction paper stuff, he smirked to himself.

What a worthless, festering bastard, he thought. He made a bet with himself that the tenant was ugly, just as ugly as his home. He looked around for a photograph and soon reeled as he saw a large portrait hanging on the wall above the fireplace.

"How did I rent to such a Neanderthal?" He gasped.

It was a disturbing specimen of humanity, like a chimp had been swallowed whole by an elephant and then shat out into some ill fitting clothes that were supposed to be smart casual wear.

This monstrosity obviously couldn't pull of smart casual wear like he could.

He smirked to himself, priding himself on his distinctive style, and then noticed that the picture over the fireplace had changed.

He squinted and leaned closer, then jumped as the image moved.

Face brilliant red, he packed up his eviction papers and scurried home.

The thick layer of dust on the mirror was the reason he hadn't realised it was a mirror. It was also the reason he'd thought his reflection looked so bad.

Yes, that was what it was, he told himself.

Title: Ingenue

She hugged the book to her chest and sighed.

She would wait forever for him. He would find her and adore her and they would be married and have beautiful babies and live in a big house and everything would be just like it was in fairy tales.

Only it would be better than fairy tales because they just say happily ever after and then stop. 

They would go on and on and on forever and he would be perfect in every way and it would feel as if he sparkled in the sunshine just like the hero in her book.

He would adore her so much that he would watch her sleep and hold onto her possessively and he'd love her so much that it terrified him but he wouldn't ever leave because she would be nothing without him and he would know that.

She'd tell him how empty her life is without him and that she'd do something stupid if he left her.

She found her Edward at a coffee shop and he was everything she had hoped for.

It was hard to explain to the police exactly why she was repeatedly violating her restraining order for a perfect stranger, but when she showed them her book they seemed to understand.

Title: Vintage

Crow's feet, shrivelled tits, thin white hair and brittle bones.

Music was crap these days and young people are all so rude.

Her teeth went out more than she did and all chairs seemed to be too low.

She thought about getting a throne especially made with her pension money. Forget the denture cleaner this week and commission a throne.

She chuckled to herself as she sat at the bus stop. A young girl pulled out the ear plugs she was wired into and asked her, "Wot?"

"I'm a vintage Champagne you know?" 

"You're a wot?"

"And you, my dear, are a Bucks Fizz!"

Title: Time Zones

It's dark here.

Elsewhere it's light, maybe even sunny. One pole is pitch black and the other brilliant white. They're both freezing though.

Sometimes we can look up and see the dark side of the moon. Or rather we don't see it, we see that slither of moon that the light hits and call it a crescent moon.

The whole thing is there and if you really look you can see it's still a circle, it's still all there, it's still whole.

Absence makes the heart grow fonder and darkness makes things feel as if they're gone.

It's dark where I am, but I'm still here.

I'm not absent.

But I'm still fond of you lot in the light.

Title: Voracious

Maybe it was a flesh eating bacteria.

Some said it was an allergy, some said it was down to a new type of soap, and the doctor said it was a fungal infection.

There was no allergy, or new soap, or fungus anywhere around though. It could only be one thing, a flesh eating virus.

Why eat the flesh and leave the fat? If you're a virus or a bacteria you have no business being picky. There's no use in being a fussy eater and if they were going to eat away the skin they could at least trim some of the fat too.

Why peel a banana, eat the skin and throw away the good bit?

This thing was eating away at skin that was never that perfect but was kind of essential to the whole looking like a human being thing. 

Voracious little fungal things they may be but, looking in the mirror, it could only be described one way.

Flesh eating bastards!

Title: Escapade 

Bob and Esther made sure the coast was clear.

One of the prison guards passed on her patrol and they ducked back into their hiding place. A whistle caught their attention and they looked up to see one of the cleaners nodding towards the open door to the recreation area.

Bob shook his head, he was too old for jumping the wall and Esther would never make it.

The cleaner cleared his throat and patted at his wheel along cart full of cleaning products, mops and brooms. He pulled it back, blocking one half of the walkway, and then went through the open door to pick up some bags of garden rubbish from the recreation area. he stared throwing them into the space at the other half of the walkway.

"Run for it!" Bob whispered to Esther.

They both made a break for the space between rubbish bags and cleaning cart.

The cleaner stooped to fill the last of the bags with leaves, the coast was clear of guards, and they had a chance of getting out through the door where the bins were kept. 

"If we get onto the other side of the wheelie cart we can sneak out as he opens the door to take it outside!" Bob said to Esther.

She was focused on her sprint for freedom, lifting her metal shackle and pushing it a little way forward, lifting and pushing, lifting and pushing.

They were almost rounding the cleaning cart when the patrolling prison guard passed by again.

"Oi, where are you going?"

"It's the commandant!" Esther said, getting her zimmerframe caught on one of the rubbish bags while Bob's walking stick banged against the plastic mop bucket as he jumped.

"Not again," the woman said as she marched towards them, "you will go back to your rooms and be nice to your grandchildren, they've come all this way to visit you."

"But they're so boring!" Bob whined.

"And they put babies on my lap so I can't get away!" Esther protested.

"Adventures later, just indulge them for half an hour, please?" The warder of the nursing home coaxed them back to their rooms and their families, scolding the cleaner for encouraging them as they went.

"Sent to the cooler again eh Esther?"

"We need to get me a motor on this thing," the old woman grumbled as she wobbled along on her walking frame.

Title: Frisky


An online tutorial, a trip to the all night supermarket half a mile away, a screwdriver set purchased, batteries picked up at the checkout just in case, a meandering walk back because you're paranoid that somebody from the supermarket is following you home, another online tutorial, a screaming hissy fit, an attempt to put the parts back together so you can at least use it as a dildo, a tantrum as this plan fails, the brutal murder of a broken vibrator with a screwdriver set.

Finally, a condom, a lubricant and a mobile phone alarm set on vibrate.

A horny single woman will always find a way.

So here's the deal: I'm a professional writer. That's my job. I write what I write, for whatever the project might be. I have the utmost respect for you, and honestly want you to like my work, but I can't let that affect my story decisions. Everybody wants different things from a story, but this is not a democracy, you do not get to vote. You are free to say what you think of my work, even if you hate it, I honestly don't mind. But the ONLY person I need to please is myself, and the ONLY thing I need to serve is the story. Not you. I will do my work to the very best of my ability, in an attempt to give you the best show, the best movie, the best story, the best entertainment I possibly can. Even if that means that sometimes, I'll do things you won't like. I won't debate it. Either you go along with it, or you don't. None of it is done to hurt you, or to force some agenda down your throat, or anything else. It's all in service of the story.

Seeing as this is all only writing related stuff and not seekrit identity-ish.

*changes back into seekrit identity*

Kind of a funny feeling this.

In some ways you'd think it would bum me out because my script for this show got turned down but on the other hand I must have good instincts because of all the pilots there were to pick up and write I chose the one that eventually got made.

My eye for stuff that gets commissioned for BBC One post watershed slots is spot on!

Though I would have tried to talk them out of the laughter track. That's a big shame.

Also...my Buckaroo game between Roy and Tom was much funnier. *lol*

A Brief History Of Broadley
By Shari Smith


The mighty river Broad sliced through Broadley town centre with the grace of a blunt stanley knife. It was a historic river. It flowed into the Thames, or maybe out of it, it depended on which way the earth was tilting at the time.


The town founder; a fraud incidentally, he didn't find it at all; was James Broadley. The town was named after him and the river after half of him, he had argued that the river be called Jim but he had been outvoted by the mayor and the chief constable of Broadley who were already miffed that the town had to change its name at the whim of this moron.


The mayor had lost the town to Broadley in a game of cards, he got to stay mayor but had to re-name everything and send a letter informing the town's twenty-eight residents that they now had a new address...at which twenty-two of them left in disgust.


It was in the river Broad that James Broadley had performed his, self-proclaimed, 'Miracle of the Tench'. This was when he caught a tench big enough to feed all six remaining residents of the town, once mixed with enough mashed potato, and served up as fishcakes.


It was also in the great river that the six who ate the fishcakes relieved themselves in the soon to be proclaimed, 'Revenge of the Tench'!


The following morning James Broadley was gone, leaving the town nothing but his name and a recipe for fishcakes that carried a health warning.


Because of the fish episode, the river wasn't considered to be a good source of food for the townsfolk. Because of the syncronised bout of diarrhoea, the river was also ruled-out as a source of hygienic drinking water. However, the residents of Broadley had to wait for seven years before the town grew in numbers and a plumber moved into Stansfield Road. He was hired to pipe the river underground and paid adequately.


Ninety years later the river runs forgotten through that same pipe, a great piece of plumbing going unappreciated by those walking above and taking their regular solid bowel-movements for granted.


If only they knew of the sacrifices made by those who went before them.

The End

Title: One High Note Too Far Characters/Pairing: Me and Mariah Carey fans Rating: R Note: I have had this fantasy about many people. I want to rip out their throat by punching my way through their nostril and reaching down to grab it from the inside. I want to tear off their face and throw it down onto the floor like a crappy Halloween mask and then grind it into a pulp beneath my heel. I want to cut off their sexual organs, turn them inside out, and microwave them for an hour before tipping the sizzling meat into a liquidiser and pulping the lot into a pate. Then I want to feed it to a dog with explosive diarrhoea so they can have their own mangled remains blasted into their screaming face in dogshit form. I want to rip off their eyebrows and pierce their eardrums. I want to bludgeon them to death with a cricket bat, not a baseball bat, a cricket bat. A cricket bat has corners. I want to beat them to death, urinate on the open wound of their skull and then sandpaper that fucking Mariah Carey CD that they have forced me to listen to through our adjoining wall ALL NIGHT LONG. Some say it would be unreasonable torture. I say forcing people to listen to Mariah Carey is worse.
